greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of ways the set {1,2,...,n} can be split into three subsets of equal sums.
link: Alois P. Heinz, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..125
formula: a(n) is 1/6 of the coefficient of x^0*y^0 in Product_{k=1..n} (x^(-2*k)+x^k*(y^k+y^(-k))).
maple: b:= proc() option remember; local i, j, t; `if`(args[1]=0,
mathematica: b[args_List] := b[args] = Module[{nargs = Length[args]}, If[args[[1]] == 0, If[nargs == 2, 1, b[args // Rest]], Sum[If[args[[j]] - Last[args] < 0, 0, b[Append[Sort[Flatten[Table[args[[i]] - If[i == j, Last[args], 0], {i, 1, nargs-1}]]], Last[args]-1]]], {j, 1, nargs-1}]]];
Array[a, 42] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Oct 30 2020, after _Alois P. Heinz_ *)
results.author: _Floor van Lamoen_, Oct 07 2005
ext: Extended beyond a(25) by _Alois P. Heinz_, Sep 03 2009
